Я отдаю себе \nотчет в тоМ, что наш враг не укра инцы, а еврейские \nолигархи и их аМер иканск ие курат оры (с) / We are \nfighting against the New Israel . I am aware that our \nenemy is not the Unkranians, but the Jewish oligarchs \nand their American supervisors (c) \ndiscussion 42 35 60 60 Так знач ит, и русск ий народ такой плохой, т.к. таМ \nтоЖе есть плохие, не воспитанные люди. Но и в Туве, и \nу Русск ого народа есть талантл ивые люди, которыМ и \nМоЖно гордиться. / So, the Russian people is so bad \nthen, because it includes bad, rude people. But in both \nTuva and the Russian people there are talented \npeople, which one can be proud of. \nethnophaulism 48 49 47 56 ага и ещё вспоМниМ на чей стороне воевали \nМаМалыЖн ики в ВОВ!!! / Yeah, let us now \nremember, on which side the mamalyzhnicks fought \nin WWII!!! exclam 51 45 45 55 \nirony 53 57 57 60 БезуМн о популярныМ Могло бы стать прилоЖен ие \nЯндекс.Хачи", сообщающее актуал ьные данные о \nплотности кучк ования кавказцев на станциях Метр о / \nThe Yandex.Khachi application could become insanely \npopular, providing up-to-date data on the clustering \ndensity of Caucasians clumping together at metro \nstations \nУ русск их привычка считать что победили они))” / \n“Russians have a habit of thinking that they won)) \nnoun phrase 64 45 56 47 Историческ и чувашский народ никогда не \nконфликтовал, Жил в Мире и согласии. / Historically, \nthe Chuvash people have never been in conflict, they \nlived in peace and quiet. \nobscene 54 50 56 54 якуты бл* кричат что Киеву нельзя быть с Европой.... \nэтоЖ какиМ нада быть е*нутыМ якут оМ)) / The \nYakuts f*cking cry that Kiev can’t be with Europe … \nwhat a f*cked Yakut this must be! \nother_neg 49 55 55 54 Виталий, да Мало ли что кто сказал ? бред !!!! русск ие \nсаМи разваливают свою страну ...даЖе с простого \nначн ёМ- кто срёт на природе после отдыха ? засерая \nозёра и реки ? кто засерает всё вокруг себя ? \nаМер икосы и Жиды ..всё это херня ” / “Vitaly, but do \nyou care what somebody said? nonsense !!!! Russians \nthemselves are destroying their country ... take for a \nexample, who litters in nature on a vacation? littering \nlakes and rivers? who will litter everything around \nhim? Americans and Jews .. this is bullshit \nstrong 50 36 41 48 а саМое сМешное чечены пишут постоянно Мол вы \nрусск ие нация алкашей и нарк оМанов. Мне лично \nписали всегда. а саМи то)) нарк обароны, еще и русск их \nсаЖают . гниды черн оЖопые / the funny thing is, the \nChechens always write: you, Russians, are a nation of \nalcoholics and junkies. they wrote this to me \npersonally always. Look at yourselves)) drug lords, \nand they put Russians on drugs. black-ass nits E. Pronoza et al. ', 'Information Processing and Management 58 (2021) 102674\n14Table 6 \nInstance-based hate speech detection (IBAD) results with deep learning models \nRun Model Architecture F1-hate F1-ave F1-macro \n1 LSTM�GRU TextRep 0.670a 0.834 0.727a \n2 LSTM�GRU EthnoRep \x87TextRep 0.732a,c 0.853a,b,c 0.750a,b,c \n3 MemNet See (Tang, Qin, Qin et al., 2016 ) 0.732a,c 0.849a,b,c 0.752a,b,c \n4 Convers-RuBERT�Dense Text, size \x88100, mean pooling, fine-tuned 4 last layers 0.785a,b,c, \nd,j,f 0.877a,b,c,d, \nj,f 0.797a,b,c,d, \nj,f \n5 Convers-RuBERT�Ling�Dense�Dense2 Text, pre-trained, layer sizes \x88100, mean pooling, fine- \ntuned 4 last layers 0.732a,c 0.860a,b,c,g 0.768a,b,c,e, \ng \n6 Convers-RuBERT�Ling�Dense�Dense2 EthnicGroup�Text, pre-trained, layer sizes �100, \nmean pooling, fine-tuned 4 last layers 0.813a,b,c, \nd,f,i,j 0.892a,b,c, \nd,f,h,j 0.824a,b,c, \nd,f,h,j \n7 Convers- \nRuBERT�LSTM�Ling�Dense�Dense2 EthnicGroup\x87Text, pre-trained, layer sizes \x88100, mean \npooling, fine-tuned 4 last layers 0.813a,b,c, \nd,f,i,j 0.889a,b,c,d, \nf,i,j 0.820a,b,c,d, \nh,f,j \na - significant difference from the Baseline (Table 4 run 0, p D0.01) \nb - significant difference from fine-grained features with VC (Table 4 run 3, p D0.01) \nc - significant difference from LSTM�GRU (TextRep ) (Table 6 run 1, p D0.01) \nd - significant difference from LSTM �GRU (TextRep�EthnoRep ) (Table 6 run 2, p D0.01) \ne - significant difference from LSTM �GRU (TextRep�EthnoRep ) (Table 6 run 2, p D0.05) \nf - significant difference from MemNet (Table 6, run 3, p D0.01) \ng - significant difference from MemNet (Table 6, run 3, p D0.05) \nh - significant difference from fine-tuned Convers-RuBERT (Table 6 run 4, p D0.01) \ni - significant difference from fine-tuned Convers-RuBERT (Table 6 run 4, p D0.05) \nj - significant difference from fine-tuned Convers-RuBERT with Text representation only (Table 6 run 5, p D0.01) \nBased on the 12results reported in Table 6, the following conclusions about the models performance can be made: \n≡LSTM�GRU model with word embeddings as text representation is comparable to classical machine learning models with hand- \ncrafted linguistic features; \n≡Adding ethnonym representation to both LSTM�GRU and Convers-RuBERT models significantly increases their performance; \n≡MemNet (state-of-the-art model for ABSA) performs at the same level as LSTM�GRU with ethnonym representation; \n≡Fine-tuning Convers-RuBERT with EthnicGroup�Text representation outperforms other models (LSTM�GRU, classical ma-\nchine learning models and state-of-the-art ABSA models); \n≡Linguistic features (including sentiment and other contextual information), additional pre-training on in-domain data and an \nadditional dense layer further increase the performance of the Convers-RuBERT model significantly. \nIn terms of F1-macro, our best run in the three-class IBAD approach to hate speech detection scored 0.824. \nFinally, one of our assumptions was that the underlying structure of ethnicity-targeted hate speech is better described with three \n(positive, negative, neutral) rather than two (hate, non-hate) classes. Indeed, the assumption has been confirmed: hate speech \ndetection with the three-class IBAD approach resulted in higher performance in terms of F1-hate: 0.813 (IBAD ) against 0.760 (BAD). \n6.Error analysis & discussion \nTo interpret the results of instance-based hate speech detection, we manually analyzed the errors of our model performance in the \ninstance-based attitude detection approach, as it performed better than the binary attitude-detection approach. Additionally, to \ndemonstrate the contribution of ethnic information included in the input representation of the deep learning models, we performed a \ndeeper analysis of the difference between our best-performing BERT-based model with and without adding ethnonym information as \nan auxiliary sentence. \nIn the analysis of the model errors, first the errors were identified automatically against the ground truth, as part of the model \nevaluation (see Section 4. Methodology). Next, we annotated the errors manually in terms of their linguistic nature, similar to the \nqualitative analysis of hate speech detection errors performed by Corazza et al. (2020) . \n6.1. Error annotation \nWe performed a second annotation as part of the error analysis, in order to further understand the linguistic phenomena causing \nerrors. \nFirst, a sample output of the models was selected randomly from our test datasets (each test fold in the 10-fold cross-validation). We \nselected four representative models for our analysis: the best traditional classifier (VC, run 3 from Table 4), the best LSTM�GRU run \n(run 2 from Table 6) and two runs of BERT: run 4 (Convers-RuBERT�Dense ) and the best run 6 from Table 6 (Convers- \nRuBERT�Ling�Dense�Dense2 ). Having four models, we resulted in 24 possible error combinations of correct/incorrect pre-\ndictions. For each of these 16 types of combinations, we randomly selected three instances (one for each of the three true classes: \n12 Detailed training configuration of our best performing model can be found in Appendix. 4 E. Pronoza et al. ', 'Information Processing and Management 58 (2021) 102674\n15positive, negative and neutral) from each of the ten test folds. Since our dataset is unbalanced, for some error combinations there were \nnot all the three classes present in the examples. In this case in our error sample we gave preference to the negative class, implying hate \nspeech. The resulting error annotation dataset consists of 473 instances: 182 negative, 176 neutral and 115 positive instances. \nSecond, we engaged four annotators: two researchers in Social Informatics (one PhD, one BSc-level), and two in Computational \nLinguistics (one PhD, one MSc-level). The task included annotating each instance represented by a pair (ethnic group, text) in the sample \noutput with labels of relevant linguistic phenomena present in the corresponding text. More than one label could be assigned to one \ninstance. The labels and the examples of texts representing them are given in Table 6. The total set of labels with their brief description \nis presented in Appendix 2. Each annotator also assigned a specific mark to each instance indicating their agreement with the initial \nclass annotation. \nNext, we calculated the inter-annotator agreement in the second annotation between the label sets assigned by four annotators (see \nAppendix 3). Krippendorff ’s alpha was applied. The agreement was generally medium (0.39-0.56) between the pairs of annotators, \nwith the exception of two computational linguists reaching the agreement of 0.81. The annotators agreed on the correct class labels \nwith each other and with the golden annotation only in 67% cases. This additionally confirms the complexity of both interpreting the \nauthor ’s attitude towards ethnic groups and detecting specific linguistic phenomena in text. \n6.2. Error analysis \nTaking into account the complexity and low agreement of our annotation, we have selected the frequent labels which, when applied \nby at least one annotator to an instance, were agreed upon by at least three of the four annotators in more than 50% of the cases. We \nreport statistics for these labels in Table 6. For each of the four selected models (VC, LSTM�GRU, Convers-RuBERT�Dense, \nConvers-RuBERT�Ling�Dense�Dense2 ) we present the percentage of cases, where the respective model gave an incorrect pre-\ndiction. In other words, the percentages indicate how difficult the current linguistic phenomenon is for a specific classifier. \nThe preliminary error sample analysis has shown that there is no strong variation in model performance across different labels. \nHowever, there are some tendencies. \nFirstly, the traditional classifier (VC) is worse at detecting hate speech towards ethnic groups when the group is referred to as a \nnoun phrase , than neural networks. It can be explained by the fact that VC uses one-hot encoding of words and phrases and ethnicity- \nbased features are extracted using a dictionary of ethnonyms, whereas in LSTM and BERT approaches words are represented by their \nembeddings. The latter obviously allows the models to identify ethnic groups represented by more complex means than by single-word \nethnonyms. \nSecondly, VC is better for texts with contrasting opinions where both positive and negative lexicon is used (other_neg ). Indeed, VC \nmainly focuses on the nearest context words of ethnonyms. When several ethnic groups are mentioned in the text, and hate speech \ntowards another ethnicity is used in the text, VC appears to be better than neural network-based models (LSTM�GRU and Convers- \nRuBERT ). \nThirdly, texts where hate targeted at ethnicities is expressed with negative lexicon in the nearest context of ethnonyms (con-\ntext_neg ) or with strong negative sentiment words (strong ) are easier to classify for all models, than texts where such attitude is \nexpressed in a more implicit way: describing actions attributed to ethnic groups, or using ironic language. Hate expressed with \nobscene words is also relatively difficult for the models to detect, perhaps, due to the lack of creative derivatives of obscene words and \nexpressions in the sentiment dictionary and in word embeddings. \nFinally, Convers-RuBERT enhanced with linguistic features and pre-training appears by far the best model at detecting ethnicity- \ntargeted hate speech represented by a contrast to another ethnic group. \nIndeed, a number of hate speech examples in RuEthnoHate demonstrate a certain level of creativity, making the hate speech subtle \nand difficult to classify. In Ex. (4) below, the author first expresses ironic admiration and gratitude towards his interlocutor and \ngeneralizes their attitude over the Ukranian people. Then the author proceeds to mutual derogatory comments between Russians and \nUkranians, ironically promising that the Russians will meet the derogatory expectations. \n(4) Эдик, ну ты и впряМ великий Укр)). ПряМ такой уМны й, ваЖны й, уваЖае Мый, богатый, великодушный. Спасибо ВаМ, за то что \nучитете нас ватников и азиатов. Спасибо ВаМ за Мир, за человечест во и Чёрное Море. Мы кацапы будеМ вести себя хорошо и газ ваМ \nбудеМ давать бесплатн о. А Путина Мы выгониМ в Ростов, пусть таМ сидят тираны пенсионеры. ОбещаеМ сЖеч ь все покрышки и \nобосать все дворы Москвы. ОбещаеМ как и вы встать ракоМ и сМазат ь зад и Ждать друзей из АМер ики. Нет ну не бесплатн о, пусть наМ \nза это кредиты дают. \nEd, you are really a great Ukr)). So clever, influential, respected, rich, generous. Thank you for teaching us, vatniks and Asians . \nThank you for Peace, for humanity and for the Black sea. We, katsaps , will behave well and will give you gas for free. We will send \nPutin away to Rostov, to other tyrants and retirees. We promise to burn all the tires and piss in all the yards in Moscow. We promise to \nget down on all fours, like you, lubricate our ass and wait for our friends from America . Not for free, let them give us money loans for \nthat. \n(5) И это только одно из тысяч предприятий, которые понастр оили озверелые русак и на вильних зэМлях нэньки. Оголтелая , вечно \nпьяная и неМытая русня , сМес ь татар и Мордвы, загадила Укра инушку своиМи фабр икаМи, заводаМи, школаМи, больницаМи, \nэлектр останцияМи и МногоэтаЖныМ и ЖилыМ и доМаМ и. Не было предела этой циничной, бесчел овечной оккупации. Народ был \nзапуган и порбащён. Но справедливость восторЖест вовала! Майдан!!!!!!! Скинули кляте ярМо! Долой душные панел ьки! Наза д, к \nприроде, к МазанкаМ и копанкаМ . Слава Урка ине. \nAnd this is a single enterprise out of thousands, which were built by the outraged Rusacks on the free lands of nenka [misspellings \nimitating the Ukranian language]. Unbridled, eternally drunk and dirty Rusnya , a mix of Tatars and Mordva , has shitted the beloved E. Pronoza et al. ', 'Information Processing and Management 58 (2021) 102674\n16Ukraine with its factories, plants, schools, hospitals, power stations and multi-storey houses. The cynical, inhuman occupation was \nunlimited. The people were terrified and enslaved. But justice has prevailed! Maidan!!!!!!! The damn yoke is thrown off [misspellings \nimitating the Ukranian language]! Get rid of the stuffy multi-storey houses! Back to nature, to wattle and daub huts. Long live Ukraine \n[originally: Urkaine, a derogatory misspelling reminiscent of “Urki ”, a Russian slang name for “jailbirds ”]. \nExample (5) imitates accusations of Russians by Ukranians in an exaggerated and ironic manner, in effect demonstrating a strong \nnegative attitude towards Ukranians, also mockingly imitating the Ukranian language and pronunciation and using offensive \nmisspellings. \nThe examples above demonstrate that there are texts in our corpus containing highly complex hate speech instances, not only \ntargeting different ethnic groups with opposite attitudes, but also containing irony, imitative and derogatory misspellings, uncon -\nventional forms of obscene lexicon and references to specific historical actions and political statements. These findings confirm the \nlinguistic error categories identified by Corazza et al. (2020) in English, German and Italian hate speech detection, involving implicit \nabuse: sarcasm, jokes, the usage of negative stereotypes, or supposedly objective statements implying some form of offense; and \ncomplex syntactic structure: more than one negation or questions, anaphoric elements referring to previous messages, and examples \nrequiring external knowledge to be understood. \n6.3. Effect of adding ethnic information to Convers-RuBERT \nIn this paper we address ethnicity-targeted hate speech detection, and the ethnic aspect is important in this task. Interestingly, the \nresults show that both Convers-RuBERT and LSTM/GRU models benefit from including ethnic information in the input representation \nof the data. To confirm that ethnic representation plays an important role in our best-performing BERT-based model, we compared our \nbest-performing BERT model Convers-RuBERT�Ling�Dense�Dense2 with EthnicGroup�Text (see the best run 6 in Table 5) with \nthe same model accounting for Text representation only (see run 5 in Table 5). Specifically, we obtained the highest results by adding \nan ethnic group to the input representation, thus making it a sentence-pair classification task instead of a single-sentence classification \none. \nThe results demonstrate that adding specific ethnonym information as an auxiliary sentence and treating the problem as a sentence- \npair classification task significantly improves the performance of instance-based ethnicity-targeted hate speech detection with BERT. \nTo obtain a deeper understanding of the improvement, we illustrate the performance of the EthnicGroup�Text- and Text-based \nmodels with their confusion matrices in Table 7. \nFrom Table 7 it is obvious that adding the ethnonym information as EthnicGroup�Text representation to our best model is \nespecially useful in correcting positive and neutral instances misclassified as hateful instances, i.e. it increases the Precision of the \n“hate ” class classification. This reflects the intended effect of the added ethnonym representation: to discern the different (sometimes \npolarized) attitude towards the different ethnic groups mentioned in the same text. We demonstrate this case with examples 6-8, where \nthe target instances (emphasized in bold) are correctly classified as positive or neutral by our best model with EthnicGroup�Text, and \nmisclassified as hateful by the model with Text - evidently, because of the hate directed at other ethnic groups mentioned in the text or \ngeneral hate towards an interlocutor (respective hateful passages are underlined): \n(6) Qa, а конкретн о, кто вы по национальности? Вот я,наприМер, по Матер и-Русск ий,по отцу-Табасаране ц. А вы,чать, азерб от или \nеще какая сеМитская блядь? Ты даЖе не прена длеЖишь к кавказской расе, ты ебаны й сеМит. От тебя воняет дЖудаМи. \nQa, what is your nationality specifically? For example, I am Russian by my mother, Tabasaran by my father. Are you probably \nAserbot [ethnophaulism for Aserbaijani] or another Semitic bitch? You don’t even belong to the Caucasian race, you fucking Semit. \nYou reek of Jews. \n(7) Игорь, да кавказцы по натуре гораздо частне й чеМ укры, у Меня куМ овья арМяне уЖе 30 лет, друзья разных национальностей и \nвсе норМал ьные люди, но нет у Меня ни одного друга из хохлов, только знакоМые и те говно не люди, Жрут русск ий хлеб и не дово льны \nрусск иМи, когда гово рю валите к себе в укропию, так нет таМ плохо. \nIgor, yes, Caucasians are much more honest than Ukrs, my relatives are Armenian for 30 years, friends of various nationalities and \nall are normal people, but I have no friends among Khokhols [ethnophaulism for Ukranian], I only know some people and they are shit, \nThey eat Russian bread and are unhappy with Russians, when I say ‘go back to your Ukropia [derogatory misspelling for Ukraine], no, \nit is too bad there. \n(8) Крут ой, А что с ваМи в дебаты вступать. У вас вест Мир не прав только русск ие правы. От росси батько отказался ,казах и нахер \nпослал и, и впредачу вы еще у АрМян на косячили и считаете себя правыМи. \nKrutoy, why should I even bother discussing with you. For you, the whole world is wrong, only Russians are right. Bat’ko [informal \nfor the president of Belorussia] has given you up, Kazakhs have fucked you, and you have also screwed up with Armenians and are still \nthinking you are right. \nAt the same time, adding ethnic information to text representation in BERT increases the Recall of the “hateful ” class by capturing \nspecific patterns of relations between ethnic groups and other important tokens in the text. To illustrate such patterns captured by the \nmodel, we prepared visualization of the attention mechanism in our best-performing Convers-RuBERT�Ling�Dense�Dense2 with \nEthnicGroup�Text model using the bertviz13 tool. We selected hateful instances which Convers-RuBERT�Ling�Dense�Dense2 \nwith EthnicGroup�Text was able to predict correctly, while the same model with Text representation only misclassified them. \n13 https://github.com/jessevig/bertviz E. Pronoza et al. ', 'Information Processing and Management 58 (2021) 102674\n17In Fig. 3, attention visualization for one of the selected hateful instances is presented using the “neuron view ” mode from bert-\nviz1314. This view illustrates the flow of attention from the token on the left to the complete sequence of tokens on the right: tokens \nwhich are paying attention are shown in the left column, while the tokens being paid attention to are in the right column. The brighter \nthe color of the square next to the rightmost tokens, the more attention is being paid to those tokens. The text can be translated as “liu, \nha-ha-ha a Ukrainian will be teaching me the history of the Armenians? did we hide behind the backs of the Turks? do you even understand what \nyou said? And behind the back of the Russians …”. As it can be seen in Fig. 3, the [CLS] token which is known for capturing the core \nsemantic information about our text does pay attention to the first sentence “хохол” (ethnophaulism for the Ukrainian) - the word \ndenoting the target of the above comment. It also pays attention to the pronoun referring to the ethnic group in question (“ты” / “you”), \nand the nouns and pronouns referring to the other ethnic groups in the text (“турк ов” / ”the Turks ”, “арМян ” / ”the Armenians ”, and \n“Меня ” / “me” obviously referring to the Armenians). The text contains several mentions of different ethnic groups, and the author ’s \nattitude towards them is different: the author is hateful towards the Ukrainians but neutral towards the other ethnicities. Thus, to \ndifferentiate among these ethnicities it is important to pay attention to the ethnicity in the first one out of the two sentences (“хохол” / \n“the Ukrainian ” in our case), since in this instance, the model is predicting attitude towards this ethnic group. \n7.Limitations and ethical considerations \nDespite the significant theoretical and experimental achievements, our study has a number of limitations, which should be taken \ninto account when generalizing the results to ethnicity-targeted hate speech detection, also in other languages, and to detection of hate \nspeech directed at other groups or individuals. First, the inter-annotator agreement at all stages of our work, including dataset \nannotation and error analysis, was modest. Probably, this has to do with the fact that ethnicity-related hate speech is still an evolving \nnotion with no clear boundaries, especially in cases where creative and unconventional language is used. It is also important to note \nthat we are currently identifying ethnic groups in text with a simple lexical approach: including more complex cases of ethnic group \nmentions is a separate task, which obviously has to be solved in a real-life scenario, and it is beyond the scope of this paper. Finally, we \ncompletely miss cases of ethnicity-targeted speech where the targets are not mentioned explicitly - either due to co-reference, me-\ntonymy or other indirect indications of ethnic groups. \nOur study has some important ethical considerations as well. First of all, the models automatically detecting hate speech should by no \nmeans be used to stigmatize the authors. These tools should only be applied in addition to, and not in replacement of, expert judgement. \nCurrent work on hate speech detection is primarily aimed at obtaining scientific insights into the diverse phenomena of hate speech, not \nat automatic penalization of authors in social media. Second, neither this research is aimed at stigmatizing hate speech targets; the \navailability of hate speech examples in our publications and in our dataset does not imply our agreement with the judgements of hateful \nauthors. Nor our negative attitude towards certain ethnic groups is implied in the cases that were marked up as non-negative by an-\nnotators, but may sound negative to some of our readers. As we are making our dataset public, we believe that the best ways to avoid the \nlisted stigmatization dangers are (1) to restrict its use for research purposes only, (2) to anonymize authors and (3) to make available \ninitial diverse annotations instead of classes, in order to fully illustrate the disagreement and the complexity of the issue. \n8.Conclusions and future work \nIn this work, we aimed at detecting ethnicity-targeted negative attitudes, implying hate speech, in Russian social media texts. \nTo achieve this, we have created the RuEthnoHate dataset containing texts mentioning numerous Russian ethnic groups, and \nannotated the corpus in a fine-grained instance-level manner. We have adopted a broad definition of hate speech based on the negative \nattitude towards ethnic groups. The annotation involved 3 classes: positive, neutral, and negative attitude towards ethnic groups, with \nthe latter implying ethnicity-targeted hate speech. \nWe have carried out experiments on hate speech detection with text-level binary attitude detection (BAD) and trinary instance- \nbased attitude detection (IBAD ) approaches with classical machine learning and deep learning models. Text representation \nincluded simple unigrams, Word2vec trained on our large RuEthnics dataset (Word2vec-Ethno ), the Russian National Corpus \n(Word2vec-RNC ), and Conversational RuBERT embeddings (RuBERT-emb ). The classical machine learning models applied were \nNaive Bayes, Logistic Regression, SVM and ensemble thereof (Voting Classifier, VC). Deep learning models were built with \nLSTM�GRU and Conversational RuBERT (Convers-RuBERT ) architectures. Our best results were obtained on the IBAD approach. \nConvers-RuBERT outperformed both classical machine learning and LSTM�GRU models. However, the results of Convers-RuBERT Table 7 \nConfusion matrices for Convers-RuBERT \x87Ling\x87Dense\x87Dense2 models EthnicGroup\x87Text and Text only representations \nClassified by: EthnicGroup�Text / Text \nCorrect -1 0 1 \n1,610/1,497 311/390 119/153 -1 \n283/390 8,110/8,029 307/281 0 \n75/160 275/313 970/847 1 \n14 There are disagreements in the NLP community about the value of attention diagrams for interpreting attention-based models [Jain & Wallace \n2019 ; Wiegreffe & Pinter 2019 ]. However, we present the attention diagrams for illustration, rather than verification purposes. E. Pronoza et al. ', 'Information Processing and Management 58 (2021) 102674\n18were significantly improved with hand-crafted linguistic features, including sentiment lexicon, in-domain pre-training and an addi-\ntional dense layer, reaching F1-hate \x880.813, F1-macro \x880.824. \nTo the best of our knowledge, our research is the first study of hate speech in the Russian language targeted at ethnic minorities. Our \nresults lead to the following conclusions: \n≡Ethnicity-targeted hate speech should be addressed with the instance-based three-class approach including negative, neutral and \npositive attitudes (RQ1) ; \n≡Instance-based ethnicity-targeted hate speech detection significantly benefits from including ethnic information into the input text \nrepresentation in BERT (RQ2), which is a novel approach to this task; \n≡In instance-based ethnicity-targeted hate speech detection, state-of-the-art deep learning models significantly benefit from a \ncombination of linguistic and sentiment features with BERT pre-training and an additional dense layer, but not from linguistics \nfeatures separately (RQ3). \nMoreover, we are making available to the research community the RuEthnoHate dataset containing 5,5K social media texts, the \nfirst dataset annotated with ethnicity-targeted hate speech in Russian. \nAs future work, we plan to increase the performance of ethnicity-targeted hate speech detection models in Russian by enriching our \ndataset and taking into account the following phenomena: (a) meaningful misspellings, including unconventional obscene forms and \nimitations of foreign accent and language; (b) irony; and (с) other contrasting expressions involving complex narrative logic. \nFinally, we plan to perform experiments on ethnicity mention detection and classification, and integrate our models into a fully \nautomatic hate speech detection tool identifying both hate speech and its ethnic group targets in Russian social media texts.,15,16 \nFig. 3.Visualization of attention in Convers-RuBERT�Ling�Dense�Dense2 with EthnicGroup�Text: attention directed at “хохол” (ethno -\nphaulism for the Ukrainian) \n15 Results are only reported for the strong hate class in [Bojanowski et al., 2017] . The authors also evaluated their model on the two different \ncorpora separately, and we only selected the best result out of the two reported ones. \n16 In [Farha & Magdy, 2020] the authors performed both intra-dataset and cross-dataset experiments with 5 different datasets. We include their \naverage intra-dataset F1 score in Table 1. E. Pronoza et al. ', 'Information Processing and Management 58 (2021) 102674\n19Credit author statement \nEkaterina Pronoza : Methodology, Software, Formal Analysis, Investigation, Data Curation, Visualization, Writing - Original Draft \nPolina Panicheva : Methodology, Software, Validation, Formal Analysis, Investigation, Writing - Original Draft, Writing - Review \n& Editing \nOlessia Koltsova : Conceptualization, Methodology, Data Curation, Writing - Review & Editing, Supervision, Project adminis -\ntration, Funding acquisition \nPaolo Rosso : Conceptualization, Methodology, Supervision \nDeclaration of Competing Interest \nThe authors have no competing interests to declare. \nAcknowledgements \nThis work is an output of a research project implemented as part of the Basic Research Program at the National Research University \nHigher School of Economics (HSE University). \nThis work is the result of the collaboration with Paolo Rosso in the framework of his virtual online internship at the National \nResearch University Higher School of Economics due to COVID-19. Pronoza et al. ', 'Information Processing and Management 58 (2021) 102674\n20(continued ) \n(Mollas et al., \n2020 ) Youtube \x87Reddit (1K) gender, race, national origin, disability, religion, sexual \norientation 2 Fine-tuned BERT 0.744 \n(Moon et al., \n2020 ) News comments \n(9.4K) - Korean gender, other 2 KoBERT \x87BiLSTM 0.681 \nAppendix 2.Error annotation labels \nLabel Description \nnot_clear Is it not clear what the text is about \nirony Author is ironic towards target ethnic group \nimplicit Author ’s attitude is implicit; ethnic group may not be even mentioned in the text; we can guess what the attitude is based on our knowledge of \nthe world and political agenda, etc. \nindirect Attitude towards ethnic groups is expressed by showing attitude of other people/nations towards this ethnic group \ncontext_pos Words conveying positive sentiment towards ethnic group in the context of ethnonym(s) \ncontext_neg Words conveying negative sentiment towards ethnic group in the context of ethnonym(s) \nnoncontext_pos Words conveying positive sentiment towards ethnic group out of the context of ethnonym(s) (far from ethnonym in the text) \nnoncontext_neg Words conveying negative sentiment towards ethnic group out of the context of ethnonym(s) (far from ethnonym in the text) \ngeneral_pos General positive sentiment expressed in text (NOT towards ethnicities) - including sentiment towards author ’s interlocutor \ngeneral_neg General negative sentiment expressed in text (NOT towards ethnicities) - including sentiment towards author ’s interlocutor \nother_pos Positive sentiment expressed towards OTHER ethnic group mentioned in the same text \nother_neg Negative sentiment expressed towards OTHER ethnic group mentioned in the same text \nnegation_pos Positive attitude towards ethnic group is expressed using phrases preceded with negation (e.g., "they could never offend anyone") \nnegation_neut Neutral attitude towards ethnic group is expressed using phrases preceded with negation (e.g., "it’s not that they did something bad...") \nnegation_neg Negative attitude towards ethnic group is expressed using phrases preceded with negation (e.g., "they don’t’ want to work") \nactions Attitude towards ethnic group is expressed by the description of its actions including those taken during some historical events (e.g., a particular \nethnic group showed its prowess and strength in the military confrontation with other ethnic groups/nations; or an ethnic group is well-known \nfor its hospitality) \nquestion_pos Positive attitude towards ethnic group is expressed by a question \nquestion_neut Neutral attitude towards ethnic group is expressed by a question \nquestion_neg Negative attitude towards ethnic group is expressed by questioning positive qualities of it (e.g., "have you seen them do anything good?") \ncall Text contains call for aggression against ethnic group \nethnophaulism Ethnic group is described using ethnophaulism(s) \ncontrast Attitude towards ethnic group is shown by contrasting a particular ethnic group to other ethnic group(s) \nnoun phrase Ethnic group or a person of this group is referred to by a noun phrase "adjective \x87noun" (e.g., "russian people, turkish nation, american \nbusinessman etc.") \ndiscussion Ethnic group is mentioned in a discussion where both positive and negative lexicon is used and contrasting opinions are described (WITHOUT \nexpressing author ’s attitude towards ethnic group) \nquote Text is a quotation from a historical novel / poem / song / film / etc. \nanaphora Attitude towards ethnic group is expressed using phrases with anaphoric reference towards this ethnic group \ncaps CAPS LOCK expressing strong sentiment \nstrong Strong sentiment \nexclam Sentiment is expressed using exclamation marks \nprejudice Negative attitude towards ethnic group is due to prejudice against this ethnic group \nobscene Negative attitude towards ethnic group is expressed using obscene words \nno_ethnonym Ethnic group is not mentioned in the text (it was annotated by mistake) \nAppendix 3.Experts agreement (Krippendorff ’s alpha) \nAssessor Expert 1 Expert 2 Expert 3 Expert 4 \nExpert 1 1.00 0.56 0.39 0.51 \nExpert 2 0.56 1.00 0.50 0.81 \nExpert 3 0.39 0.50 1.00 0.43 \nExpert 4 0.51 0.81 0.43 1.00 E. In Proceedings of the Wvaluation Campaign of Natural \nLanguage Processing and Speech tools for Italian (pp. 86–95). \nCorazza, M., Menini, S., Cabrio, E., Tonelli, S., & Villata, S. (2020). A multilingual evaluation for online hate speech detection. ACM Transactions on Internet Technology \n(TOIT), 20(2), 1–22. \nWigand, C., & Voin, M. (2017). Speech by Commissioner Jourov ˘a—10 years of the EU Fundamental Rights Agency: A call to action in defence of fundamental rights, \ndemocracy and the rule of law. Retrieved from http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-17-403_en.htm . \nDavidson, T., Warmsley, D., Macy, M., & Weber, I. (2017). (2017). AAAI Press . \nDel Vigna, F., Cimino, A., Dell’Orletta, F., Petrocchi, M., & Tesconi, M. (2017). Hate me, hate me not: Hate speech detection on Facebook. Pronoza et al. ', 'Information Processing and Management 58 (2021) 102674\n23Van Hee, C., Lefever, E., Verhoeven, B., Mennes, J., Desmet, B., De Pauw, G., & Hoste, V. (2015). Detection and fine-grained classification of cyberbullying events. In \nInternational Conference Recent Advances in Natural Language Processing (RANLP) (pp. 672–680). \nVirtanen, P., Gommers, R., Oliphant, T. E., Haberland, M., Reddy, T., Cournapeau, D., & van der Walt, S. J. (2020). SciPy 1.0: Fundamental algorithms for scientific \ncomputing in Python. Nature methods, 17(3), 261–272. \nWagner, J., Arora, P., Vaíllo, S. C., Barman, U., Bogdanova, D., Foster, J., & Tounsi, L. (2014). DCU: Aspect-based Polarity Classification for SemEval Task 4. Learning Latent Opinions for Aspect-level Sentiment Classification. In AAAI (pp. 5537 –5544). \nWarner, W., & Hirschberg, J. (2012). Detecting hate speech on the World Wide Web. Predictive features for hate speech detection on twitter. In Proceedings of the NAACL student \nresearch workshop (pp. 88–93). \nWiedemann, G., Yimam, S. M., & Biemann, C. (2020). UHH-LT & LT2 at SemEval-2020 Task 12: Fine-Tuning of Pre-Trained Transformer Networks for Offensive \nLanguage Detection. arXiv preprint arXiv:2004.11493 . \nWiegreffe, S., & Pinter, Y. (2019). Attention is not not Explanation. In Proceedings of the 2019 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing and the 9th \nInternational Joint Conference on Natural Language Processing (EMNLP-IJCNLP) (pp. 11–20). \nWilliams, M. (2019). SemEval-2019 Task 6: Identifying and Categorizing Offensive Language in Social \nMedia (OffensEval). In Proceedings of the 13th International Workshop on Semantic Evaluation (pp. 75–86). \nZhang, Z., Robinson, D., & Tepper, J. (2018). Detecting hate speech on twitter using a convolution-GRU based deep neural network. In European semantic web \nconference (pp. 745–760). Springer, Cham. \nZueva, N.; Kabirova, M., & Kaliadin, P. (2020). Reducing Unintended Identity Bias in Russian Hate Speech Detection. https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.11666 . E. Pronoza et al. '], ['Abuse is Contextual, What about NLP?\nThe Role of Context in Abusive Language Annotation and Detection\nStefano Menini\nFondazione Bruno Kessler\nTrento, Italy\nmenini@fbk.euAlessio Palmero Aprosio\nFondazione Bruno Kessler\nTrento, Italy\naprosio@fbk.euSara Tonelli\nFondazione Bruno Kessler\nTrento, Italy\nsatonelli@fbk.eu\nAbstract\nThe datasets most widely used for abusive lan-\nguage detection contain lists of messages, usu-\nally tweets, that have been manually judged as\nabusive or not by one or more annotators, with\nthe annotation performed at message level. In\nthis paper, we investigate what happens when\nthe hateful content of a message is judged also\nbased on the context, given that messages are\noften ambiguous and need to be interpreted in\nthe context of occurrence. We ﬁrst re-annotate\npart of a widely used dataset for abusive lan-\nguage detection in English in two conditions,\ni.e. with and without context. Then, we\ncompare the performance of three classiﬁca-\ntion algorithms obtained on these two types of\ndataset, arguing that a context-aware classiﬁca-\ntion is more challenging but also more similar\nto a real application scenario.\n1 Introduction\n‘Abuse is contextual’ is one of the key claims re-\nported in (Prabhakaran et al., 2020), where the\nauthors describe the content of a panel with NLP\npractitioners and human rights experts at the Hu-\nman Rights Conference RightsCon 2020. A similar\nremark is made in (Jurgens et al., 2019) in a recent\nposition paper on current NLP methods to ﬁght\nonline abuse, arguing that NLP research tends to\nconsider a narrow scope of what constitutes abuse,\nwithout respecting, for instance, community norms\nin classiﬁcation decisions. Similarly, (Vidgen et al.,\n2019) claim that one of the main research chal-\nlenges concerning abusive language detection is ac-\ncounting for context, although they focus mainly on\nuser-level variables and network representations.\nIn this work, we present an analysis aimed at\nbetter understanding what context is in abusive lan-\nguage detection, and what its effects are on data\nannotation and classiﬁcation. We focus on dis-\ncourse context, i.e. the messages preceding a given\ntweet, because it has been relatively understudiedin abusive language detection, while user-level and\nnetwork-level features have already been exten-\nsively discussed in past works (Fehn Unsvåg and\nGambäck, 2018; Del Tredici et al., 2019; Liu and\nWeber, 2014; Sap et al., 2019; Caselli et al., 2020).\nConsider for example the following tweet:\n@User1: hell yeah bitches hate that shit\nWithout any context, an annotator may think\nthat it has an abusive content, aimed at offending\nsomeone by calling them ‘bitches’, and its offen-\nsive intent is strengthened by the use of ‘that shit’.\nHowever, our judgement would change if we knew\nthat the preceding tweet is:\n@User2 Ima stop calling females bitches\nnext week sometime. Just tryin to get that\nbitch word out of my vocabulary\nIndeed, the context would show that the two\nusers are probably friends and that the message by\n@User1 is a sort of joke. The main goal of this\npaper is to analyse what is the impact of cases like\nthis when detecting abusive language on Twitter,\nboth manually and automatically. In particular, the\nmain research questions we want to address are:\nR1: How would abusive language annotation\nchange if we provided annotators also with\nthe textual context preceding a tweet? Would\nabusive judgements increase or decrease?\nR2: What would classiﬁcation performance be like\nif we used abusive language datasets anno-\ntated with context? Which algorithms would\nwork best and how would the performance\nchange compared to single-tweet classiﬁca-\ntion?\nTo address the above questions, we perform\na manual annotation of around 8,000 EnglisharXiv:2103.14916v1 [cs.CL] 27 Mar 2021', 'tweets in two different conditions, with and with-\nout context, and analyse what linguistic phenom-\nena contribute to different annotations of the\nsame tweets in the two settings (Section 4). We\nalso compare three supervised classiﬁcation al-\ngorithms, described in Section 5 and 6, and\nevaluate their different performance on the data\n(Section 7). Additional remarks on the experi-\nments and a proposal on how abusive language\ndetection tasks should be cast are discussed in\nSection 8. The annotated datasets are made\navailable at https://github.com/dhfbk/\ntwitter-abusive-context-dataset .\n2 Related work\nThe problem of detecting abusive language on so-\ncial media has recently gained a lot of attention in\nthe NLP community, thanks also to shared tasks on\nthe topic (Wiegand et al., 2018; Bosco et al., 2018;\nBasile et al., 2019; Carmona et al., 2018; Zampieri\net al., 2019, 2020) and the consequent availability\nof benchmarks. Most of the systems participating\nin the above tasks rely on deep learning and use\nembeddings as features, sometimes enriched with\ntweet-based surface features like the presence of\nuppercased words or exclamation marks. For exam-\nple, OffensEval organisers at Semeval 2019 report\nthat 70% of participating systems use deep learning\n(Zampieri et al., 2019), and that the best perform-\ning one in the binary classiﬁcation task (Liu et al.,\n2019) is based on ﬁne-tuned Bidirectional Encoder\nRepresentation from Transformer (BERT) (Devlin\net al., 2019). Also HateEval organisers at Semeval\n2019, focused on hate speech detection against im-\nmigrants and women, report that most submitted\nruns rely on deep learning (Basile et al., 2019), al-\nthough the top-ranked system in the binary task for\nEnglish uses sentence embeddings as features to\nbe fed into an SVM-based classiﬁer (Indurthi et al.,\n2019).\nWhile most approaches to hate speech detection\ntake into account only features related to the sin-\ngle message to be classiﬁed (Park and Fung, 2017;\nZhang et al., 2018b; Kshirsagar et al., 2018; Lee\net al., 2018), recent studies have highlighted the\nimportance of context in interpreting the meaning\nof a message and its possible hateful content (Jur-\ngens et al., 2019; Vidgen et al., 2019; Caselli et al.,\n2020). However, context can concern different as-\npects: some refer to user-level features and proﬁles\n(Vidgen et al., 2019), arguing that an aggressiveattitude can be identiﬁed at proﬁle level. Some\nother works suggest that incorporating information\nabout the network structure of a user is beneﬁcial to\nthe detection of hate speech and abusive behaviour\n(Chatzakou et al., 2017; Fehn Unsvåg and Gam-\nbäck, 2018; Del Tredici et al., 2019). Some other\nworks suggest to consider also the annotator pro-\nﬁle, showing that messages written in a speciﬁc\ndialect may be judged differently by annotators\nwith a different ethnicity (Sap et al., 2019), biasing\nthe creation of datasets and therefore of supervised\nsystems.\nAnalysing the text surrounding a given message\nto evaluate its offensiveness, instead, is a rather\nunderstudied problem. Some works have mod-\neled and classiﬁed threads from Reddit (Almerekhi\net al., 2019) and FoxNews (Gao and Huang, 2017)\nto detect words and topics that trigger toxicity, or to\nﬁnd early discussion features that can predict con-\ntroversiality, modeling not just the content of the\ninitiating post, but also the content and structure of\nthe initial responding comments (Hessel and Lee,\n2019). These works are however different from\nours both in terms of task, of social media platform\nand of thread structure. Other works have focused\non Wikipedia, analysing linguistic cues of ongo-\ning conversations to predict their future trajectory\n(Zhang et al., 2018a), or trying to assess whether a\ncomment is toxic based only on the preceding mes-\nsages (Karan and Šnajder, 2019). The most similar\nwork to ours is probably (Pavlopoulos et al., 2020),\nwhose goal is to assess the contribution of context\nin toxicity detection. Surprisingly, they come to\nthe opposite conclusion, showing that including\nthe textual context increases the perceived toxicity.\nHowever, their setting is different, in that they fo-\ncus on Wikipedia Talk Pages and include as context\nonly the parent comment and the discussion title.\nFurthermore, the corpus that they create with a set-\nting similar to ours, i.e. by crowd-annotating with\nand without context, contains only 250 comments.\nThe same authors acknowledge that larger anno-\ntated datasets would be needed to estimate more\naccurately how often context ampliﬁes or mitigates\ntoxicity.\n3 Data Extraction and Analysis\nIn order to analyse the role of context on data an-\nnotation and classiﬁcation, we focus on the dataset\npresented in (Founta et al., 2018), which originally\nincluded around 100K tweets annotated with four', 'Original Retrieved At least 1\nDataset before\nAbusive 31,985 12,357 1,931\nNot abusive 67,814 37,091 6,087\nTotal 99,800 49,448 8,018\nDuplicates 2,017\nTable 1: Statistics on three versions of the dataset by\n(Founta et al., 2018): original, retrieved by us, subset\nhaving a previous context\nlabels: hateful, abusive, spam or none. The authors\nused a bootstrapping approach to sampling tweets,\nwhich were labelled by several crowdsource work-\ners and then validated. Differently from other hate\nspeech datasets, this was not created starting from a\nset of predeﬁned offensive terms or hashtags so as\nto reduce bias, a main issue in hate speech datasets\n(Wiegand et al., 2019). Also for this reason, the\ndataset has been widely used in experiments for\nhate speech classiﬁcation in English.\nSince the dataset includes the tweet IDs, we used\nthis information to query the Twitter API and re-\ntrieve the complete thread including the given mes-\nsage, so to leverage also the context of each tweet.\nWe then mapped the hateful and abusive tweets\nto our abusive class, while removing the spam in-\nstances. An overview of the dataset is reported\nin Table 1. The API was queried between August\nand September 2019 and the retrieval was problem-\natic because some of the tweets were not available\nanymore, conﬁrming similar remarks in previous\nworks (Klubicka and Fernández, 2018).\nAfter removing the tweets no longer available\nonline and the ones without a preceding context,\nwe obtained a new dataset consisting of 8,018 anno-\ntated tweets. As expected, the removal of messages\naffects more the abusive category, for which only\n38% of the tweets could be retrieved, while for the\nmajority non abusive class 55% of the messages\ncould be found. This may depend on the fact that\nusers decided to remove messages from their ac-\ncount, but also that some proﬁles were suspended\nin compliance with Twitter policy.\nWe also observed that the original dataset con-\ntains duplicated tweets (2,017 in total), probably be-\ncause both original and re-tweeted messages were\nannotated, and we therefore removed them.\n4 Manual (Re)annotation\nSince one of the goals of this work is to under-\nstand whether the textual context plays any role indetecting abusive messages online, we perform a\nmanual re-annotation of the tweets with context. In\nparticular, during the task, annotators not only read\nthe single tweet but also the preceding context and\nare asked to judge the abusiveness of the message\ntaking the whole conversation into account. We use\nAmazon Mechanical Turk platform to perform the\nannotation of 8,018 tweets with context.\nThe guidelines provided to crowd-workers ex-\nplicitly require the tweet to be annotated as abusive\nor not considering also what was written before in\nthe thread. To ensure a good quality of collected\nannotations, we introduced gold standard examples\nin the task (one every ﬁve tweets) and restricted the\naccess to English native speakers. All requirements\nintroduced by Mechanical Turk for tasks contain-\ning adult content, for example adding a warning in\nthe task title, were implemented. For each tweet we\ncollected 3 annotations, and the majority label was\nﬁnally assigned. Inter-annotator agreement was\n0.713 multi-rater free-marginal kappa with 85.6%\nof labels in agreement.\nIn order to enable a fair comparison between an-\nnotation with and without context, we re-annotated\nthe same tweets using the same methodology with-\nout providing crowd-workers with the tweet con-\ntext. This second annotation was performed select-\ning the same pool of crowd-workers as for the ﬁrst\ntask, so to reduce variability due to annotators’ bias\nand preferences. The task was launched around\nthree months after the completion of the ﬁrst one,\nmaking it unlikely that crowd-workers remember\nthe labels assigned to the same tweets with context.\nThis re-annotation without context was performed\nalso to make sure that the two annotated datasets\nwere tagged following exactly the same guidelines.\nIndeed, the original annotation provided in (Founta\net al., 2018) was performed by adjusting incremen-\ntally the deﬁnition of the abusive categories to be\nannotated. Although they could be mapped to a bi-\nnary classiﬁcation, the way in which the annotation\nprocess was structured may lead to different results\ncompared to our setting.\nIn Table 2 we report the distribution of abu-\nsive and non-abusive messages in the dataset\nannotated with and without context (CONTEXT\nand SINGLE-TWEET respectively). When\nannotated with context, the abusive class contains\n672 tweets less than in the annotation without\ncontext, and its weight decreases from 18% to\n10%. This shows that the main effect of context is', 'Annotations without context (SINGLE-TWEET) Annotations with context (CONTEXT)\nAt least 1 # previous tweets: At least 1 # previous tweets:\ntweet before 1 2-5 6+ tweet before 1 2-5 6+\nAbusive 1,472 699 608 165 800 404 324 72\nNot Abusive 6,546 2,794 2,747 1,005 7,218 3,089 3,031 1,098\nTotal 8,018 3,493 3,355 1,170 8,018 3,493 3,355 1,170\nTable 2: Comparison of re-annotated tweets providing crowd-workers with no context (left) or preceding context\n(right)\nto reduce the perceived offensiveness of messages,\nenabling annotators to understand the tone of the\nconversation and sometimes the relation between\nusers. The example reported below shows clearly\nthis phenomenon: if we consider the last tweet (in\nitalics) in isolation, we may think that @User2\nis aggressively terminating a phone call. Instead,\nlooking at the context we notice that this tweet is\njust a funny reply to the call mentioned by @User1.\n@User1: My next call: ‘Hi. I sent an\nemail. I got no response. Is that because\nyou’re fucking handling it, or fucking\nignoring it?’ Wish me luck.\n@User2: ‘I’m fucking hanging up now. ’\n\x03click\x03\nAnother example, reported below, shows how\nthe ironic tweet by @User2 may be labeled as\nabusive without the previous context:\n@User1: Penn State trustee says he’s not\n‘totally out’ of sympathy for Sandusky\nvictims.\n@User2: Yeah. Those damn vic-\ntims...they’re the worst! \x03shakes ﬁst in\nthe air \x03\nInterestingly, the longer the context, the more\ntweets are considered non abusive by annotators:\nfor the group of tweets having a context longer\nthan 5 tweets, only 6% of them are annotated as\nabusive. This percentage increases up to 10% when\nthe context is between 2 and 5 tweets, and 12%\nwhen only one tweet is in the context.\nOther cases include tweets whose meaning was\nunclear or underspeciﬁed, for example because of\nthe presence of anaphoric expressions, ellipsis, in-\ncomplete messages split across several tweets, etc.\nIn all these cases, the presence of context allows for\na more informed decision, reducing the interpreta-\ntion effort required to annotators. A general trendthat we observe is that, whenever a profanity is\npresent in a tweet, it is more likely to be annotated\nas abusive in the SINGLE-TWEET setting, while\nit is often labeled as non abusive in the CONTEXT\nconﬁguration. To measure this, we compute the\nmean square contingency coefﬁcient (Phi coefﬁ-\ncient) aimed at capturing the association between\nthe presence of profanities and the ‘abusive’ label.\nWe download the Google profanity words list1and\ncheck for each tweet if a profanity is present or\nnot. The Phi coefﬁcient is 0.77 for the SINGLE-\nTWEET setting, showing a very strong positive\ncorrelation between profanities and abusive labels,\nwhile it is only moderate (0.39) in the CONTEXT\nconﬁguration. This ﬁnding is in line with past\nworks, showing that the offensiveness of swearing\nis context-dependent (Pamungkas et al., 2020) and\nthat profanities are frequently used among people\nwith a strong social relationship without any offen-\nsive goal (Bak et al., 2012), but rather to signal an\ninformal attitude among the members of a commu-\nnity or even intimacy (Pei and Jurgens, 2020).\n5 Classiﬁcation algorithms\nAs a next step in our study, we want to analyse\nthe classiﬁcation performance obtained with differ-\nent algorithms on the newly annotated datasets:\nSINGLE-TWEET was annotated by providing\ncrowd-workers with tweets in isolation, and the\nsame information will be used by the classiﬁers,\nsimilar to the standard setting of hate speech de-\ntection competitions (Zampieri et al., 2019, 2020).\nThe second, CONTEXT, was annotated by show-\ning crowd-workers the tweet to be classiﬁed as well\nas all the preceding tweets retrieved from Twitter.\nLikewise, the classiﬁers will be fed also with the\ncontext at training and test time.\nWe compare two widely used deep-learning ap-\nproaches, i.e. BERT (Devlin et al., 2019) and Bidi-\n1https://github.com/RobertJGabriel/\nGoogle-profanity-words/blob/master/list.\ntxt', 'rectional LSTM (BiLSTM) (Graves and Schmid-\nhuber, 2005), as well as a non-neural one based\non Support Vector Machines (Cortes and Vapnik,\n1995). Details on the different algorithms are re-\nported below.\nBERT : This is a language representation model\ndeveloped by Google Research (Devlin et al.,\n2019), whose deep learning architecture obtained\nstate-of-the-art results in several natural language\nprocessing tasks including sentiment analysis, nat-\nural language inference, textual entailment (Devlin\net al., 2019) and hate speech detection (Liu et al.,\n2019). BERT can be ﬁne-tuned and adapted to\nspeciﬁc tasks by adding just one additional output\nlayer to the neural network. We use the base model\nof BERT for English,2trained on 3.3 billion words,\nwhich is made available on the project website.3\nFor the CONTEXT data, we adopt the conﬁgura-\ntion proposed in (Devlin et al., 2019) for sentence\npair classiﬁcation tasks: the input tweets are given\nto the classiﬁer as a pair of text chunks, with the\nﬁrst text of the pair containing the context preced-\ning the tweet, and the second one containing the\ntarget tweet. For SINGLE-TWEET data, only the\nstring of the tweet is given in input to BERT.\nBidirectional LSTMs : BiLSTMs (Graves and\nSchmidhuber, 2005) are made of a combination of\ntwo Long Short-Term Memory networks, a partic-\nular case of recurrent neural network, i.e. a clas-\nsiﬁer optimized to process sequences. Using this\ncombination, BiLSTM connects information both\nfrom previous and following statuses simultane-\nously. For CONTEXT data, we test BiLSTM in\ntwo conﬁgurations. In the ﬁrst setting , we use a\nsequence of word vectors as input. Regardless\nthe span of the context considered, the entire con-\nversation (the preceding context plus the tweet) is\nconsidered as a single text, and each word is rep-\nresented in the network through word embeddings.\nThe network is conﬁgured with three bidirectional\nlayers with respectively 128, 64 and 32 neurons.\nIn the second setting the context and the tweets\nare represented again as a sequence of word embed-\ndings. Instead of considering them as a single text,\nwe keep the tweet and its preceding messages sepa-\nrated. Both the context and the tweet move through\ntwo bidirectional layers of respectively 64 and 32\nneurons, before being merged into one to gener-\n2Uncased, 12-layer, 768-hidden, 12-heads, 110M parame-\nters.\n3https://github.com/google-research/\nbertate a prediction. Both conﬁgurations are tested\nwith different values of dropout and with different\noptimizers (see details in the following Section).\nFor SINGLE-TWEET data, only the ﬁrst setting is\nadopted.\nSVM : For the classiﬁcation we use LIBSVM\n(Chang and Lin, 2011). As for the CONTEXT data,\nthe tweet and its context are represented by con-\ncatenating a 300-dimension sentence embeddings\ngenerated from the context and a 300-dimension\nsentence embeddings for the tweet (see Section 6\nfor more details). For SINGLE-TWEET, the classi-\nﬁer is fed only with a vector of 300 dimensions.\nIn our experiments, we also evaluated other ap-\nproaches, i.e. Feed Forward Networks, Long Short-\nTerm Memory networks and Gated Recurrent Units.\nAll performed worse compared to the classiﬁcation\nalgorithms described above, therefore we do not\ninclude them in the paper.\n6 Experiments\n6.1 Preprocessing\nBefore running the classiﬁcation experiments, we\npreprocess the tweets as follows: we split hash-\ntags using Ekphrasis (Gimpel et al., 2010), which\nrecognises the tokens in a hashtag based on Google\nn-grams. The same tool is also used to replace men-\ntions with “username” and urls with “url” . We\nalso replace every instance of “money” ,“time” ,\n“date” (and in general any “number” ) with a generic\nlabel. We convert each emoji into a textual descrip-\ntion using the Python emoji package,4as suggested\nin previous work (Singh et al., 2019).\nThen, since BERT classiﬁer accepts as input\nsentences or sets of sentences, we just pass the\npre-processed tweet text or its context as is. For\nthe two other approaches, the text is converted into\nvectors in two ways, both using FastText, a library\nfor efﬁcient learning of word and sentence repre-\nsentations (Bojanowski et al., 2017; Grave et al.,\n2018). In particular, all vectors are extracted start-\ning from the pre-trained embeddings obtained from\nthe Common Crawl corpus.5Since SVM takes in\ninput sentence embeddings, we convert the context\nand the current tweet into sentence embeddings of\n300 dimensions each. Since BiLSTM takes in in-\nput word embeddings, each word is represented as\na vector of size 300 and a tweet (or context) is then\n4https://github.com/carpedm20/emoji/\n5https://fasttext.cc/docs/en/\ncrawl-vectors.html', 'obtained by merging the resulting set of vectors\ninto a matrix, used as input for the machine learn-\ning algorithm. In the ﬁrst setting , a single matrix\nis generated, containing all the vectors extracted\nfrom both the tweet and the context (if any). In\nthesecond setting , the matrices of the tweet and\nthe context are generated separately, two different\nneural networks are created and then merged in the\nlast (common) layer.\n6.2 Experimental Setup\nThe dataset we use contains 8,018 tweets, that in\none of the two conﬁgurations are preceded by a\ncontext. Note that the class balance of SINGLE-\nTWEET and CONTEXT is different (details in\nTable 2). As for the CONTEXT data, we experi-\nment with different context lengths, ranging from\n1 (i.e. only the preceding tweet) to all. Since not\nall contexts have the same length, we replace miss-\ning tweets in the context with empty strings when\na conﬁguration requires a context length that is\nhigher than the available one. This simulates a real\nscenario, in which not every tweet has a context of\nthe same size.\nAll the conﬁgurations and algorithms are evalu-\nated randomly dividing the data into training (80%),\nvalidation (10%) and test (10%). Each experiment\nis repeated three times with different random splits,\nand the results are averaged.\nFor BiLSTM,6different experiments with a\ndropout ranging from 0 to 0.5 have been com-\npared. We report only the best results, obtained\nwith dropout = 0.3. The loss function is binary\ncross-entropy and two optimizers (i.e. SGD and\nAdam) have been evaluated, although we report\nonly the results obtained with SGD which yields\na better performance. The BiLSTM is tested with\nup to 20 epochs, the results in Table 3 and 4 are\nobtained with 10 epochs. For BERT the best perfor-\nmance, reported in Table 3 and 4, is obtained with\n3 epochs (we tested up to 10 epochs), a batch size\nof 16, a max length of 256 and learning rate 2e-5.\nEvery component of the code relying on random-\nization uses 42 as seed. For SVM, we test different\ntypes of kernels (i.e. linear, polynomial or radial)\nand cost parameter (up to 100), reporting only the\nresults obtained with the best conﬁguration, i.e. lin-\near kernel and C= 50 .7\n6The BiLSTM is created with Keras 2.2.5, and runs with\nTensorﬂow-gpu 1.10.1.\n7For the experiments we use 4 Tesla P40. The BiLSTM\n(single text) takes, according to the context size, around one7 Evaluation\nWe report in Table 3 the classiﬁcation results ob-\ntained on the SINGLE-TWEET dataset, while in\nTable 4 the classiﬁer performance on the CON-\nTEXT dataset is presented, with a context window\nranging from one tweet to all those available in the\npreceding context.\nSome considerations concerning the classiﬁers’\nperformance hold for both datasets. Indeed, BERT-\nbased classiﬁcation yields the best score both in\nthe SINGLE-TWEET and in the CONTEXT set-\nting, while SVM achieves the worst performance.\nFor SVM, we tested also a different way to model\nthe context, creating a single 300-dimensional Fast-\nText embedding for the context and the tweet, but\nthe classiﬁer performance decreased. Concerning\nBiLSTM, modelling the context and the tweet to\nclassify as a single text is better than separating\nthem in two layers. In both settings, BERT yields\na much better F1 on the abusive class, the minor-\nity one, showing that it can deal with unbalanced\nclasses better than the two other approaches. We\ntested other strategies to give the tweet and the\ncontext in input to BERT, for example by merg-\ning them in a single text rather than split in two\ncolumns, following the setting proposed for single\nsentence classiﬁcation tasks in (Devlin et al., 2019),\nbut the overall performance decreased.\nConcerning the differences between the two set-\ntings, we observe that with SINGLE-TWEET all\nclassiﬁers achieve a better performance than with\nCONTEXT, and this result is consistent across all\nalgorithms and conﬁgurations. Our results suggest\nthat the classiﬁcation based only on single mes-\nsages may be easier than the context-aware one, not\nonly because of a simpler setup of the classiﬁcation\nalgorithms, but also because all the lexical infor-\nmation necessary to interpret the abusiveness of a\ntweet are present in the same message. This makes\nit easier for the classiﬁer to capture the connections\nbetween lexical elements and the corresponding\nclass, for example between profanities and the (sup-\nposed) abusiveness. Indeed, when including only\nsingle tweets, F1 is 0.893, in line with the results\nreported by participants at the last SemEval task\non abusive language detection for English, where\n60 systems achieve F1 >0.90 (Zampieri et al.,\nminute per epoch with 2.5M - 4.9M total parameters. The\nBiLSTM (separate context) takes, according to the context,\nfrom 5 to 18 minutes per epoch using 15.1M - 21.5M total\nparameters. BERT was able to run in 5 to 10 minutes per\nepoch.', 'Classiﬁer P_noAbuse R_noAbuse F1_noAbuse P_Abuse R_Abuse F1_Abuse P R F1\nBERT 0.971 0.952 0.961 0.791 0.865 0.826 0.881 0.908 0.893 \x060.007\nBiLSTM 0.952 0.958 0.955 0.796 0.775 0.785 0.874 0.866 0.870 \x060.004\nSVM 0.943 0.970 0.956 0.836 0.721 0.773 0.889 0.845 0.864 \x060,013\nMajority 0.816 1.000 0.899 0.000 0.000 0.000 0.408 0.500 0.449\nTable 3: Classiﬁcation results on SINGLE-TWEET dataset, average of three runs (with \x06StDev). Precision,\nRecall and F1 are macro-averaged.\nContext P_noAbuse R_noAbuse F1_noAbuse P_Abuse R_Abuse F1_Abuse P R F1\nBERT\n1 0.951 0.970 0.960 0.643 0.517 0.572 0.797 0.743 0.766 \x060.017\n2 0.952 0.965 0.958 0.610 0.528 0.565 0.781 0.747 0.761 \x060.017\n3 0.950 0.967 0.959 0.620 0.511 0.560 0.785 0.739 0.759 \x060.025\nAll 0.950 0.967 0.958 0.619 0.508 0.554 0.784 0.738 0.756 \x060.018\nSVM\n1 0.926 0.964 0.945 0.436 0.265 0.329 0.681 0.614 0.637 \x060.019\n2 0.928 0.962 0.945 0.446 0.291 0.352 0.687 0.627 0.649 \x060.024\n3 0.928 0.966 0.946 0.466 0.287 0.355 0.697 0.626 0.651 \x060.024\nAll 0.928 0.966 0.947 0.475 0.291 0.360 0.702 0.629 0.654 \x060.018\nBiLSTM (single text)\n1 0.939 0.956 0.947 0.494 0.404 0.439 0.716 0.680 0.693 \x060.039\n2 0.938 0.957 0.948 0.488 0.397 0.433 0.713 0.677 0.690 \x060.045\n3 0.939 0.958 0.948 0.499 0.403 0.441 0.719 0.680 0.695 \x060.040\nAll 0.937 0.960 0.948 0.500 0.381 0.428 0.718 0.671 0.688 \x060.046\nBiLSTM (separate context)\n1 0.929 0.974 0.951 0.581 0.282 0.355 0.755 0.628 0.653 \x060.040\n2 0.931 0.974 0.952 0.615 0.302 0.378 0.773 0.638 0.665 \x060.039\n3 0.926 0.974 0.950 0.548 0.254 0.314 0.737 0.614 0.632 \x060.064\nAll 0.928 0.971 0.949 0.549 0.274 0.333 0.738 0.623 0.641 \x060.050\nBaseline (majority class)\n0.900 1.000 0.947 0.000 0.000 0.000 0.450 0.500 0.474\nTable 4: Classiﬁcation results on CONTEXT dataset, average of three runs (with \x06StDev). Precision, Recall and\nF1 are macro-averaged. ‘Context’ column shows the number of preceding tweets considered as context.\n2020). Using a context-aware annotation and clas-\nsiﬁcation, instead, leads to a drop in performance,\naffecting in particular the abusive class.\nWe observe also that the context size does not\nshow a consistent impact. Furthermore, different\ncontext lengths do not have a statistically signiﬁ-\ncant effect, which we measure for each classiﬁca-\ntion algorithm using approximate randomization\ntest.\nSince in the CONTEXT dataset the number of\nabusive tweets is only 800, the lower performance\nachieved compared with SINGLE-TWEET may be\ndue to the greater class imbalance and the lower\nnumber of abusive instances in the training set,\nrather than to differences in the task. To measure\nthis effect, we run a further comparison using thesame BERT conﬁguration on both datasets, but\ndownsampling them so that they contain the same\nnumber of abusive and non abusive instances, i.e.\n800 abusive, of which 633 for training, and 6,456\nnon abusive, of which 5,232 for training. The re-\nsults of this comparison are reported in Table 5\nas the average over three runs. This additional\ncomparison conﬁrms that on the SINGLE-TWEET\ndataset BERT yields a much better performance. It\nalso shows that this difference is inherently due to\nthe way in which the task is modeled, rather than\nto the size and balance of the classes. Indeed, the\nperformance on this smaller dataset is even slightly\nbetter than on the one obtained on both datasets\nbefore downsampling.', 'SINGLE-TWEET dataset\nContext Size P_noAbuse R_noAbuse F1_noAbuse P_Abuse R_Abuse F1_Abuse P R F1\n0 0.963 0.971 0.967 0.859 0.822 0.839 0.911 0.897 0.903 \x060.006\nCONTEXT dataset\nContext Size P_noAbuse R_noAbuse F1_noAbuse P_Abuse R_Abuse F1_Abuse P R F1\n1 0.956 0.958 0.957 0.591 0.585 0.587 0.774 0.771 0.772 \x060.001\n2 0.961 0.954 0.957 0.590 0.629 0.608 0.775 0.792 0.783 \x060.013\n3 0.957 0.960 0.958 0.598 0.582 0.589 0.777 0.771 0.774 \x060.026\nAll 0.954 0.961 0.957 0.598 0.555 0.575 0.776 0.758 0.766 \x060.014\nTable 5: Classiﬁcation results using BERT on downsampled SINGLE-TWEET and CONTEXT datasets\n8 Discussion\nThe manual re-annotation of the dataset by (Founta\net al., 2018) including the preceding tweets high-\nlighted the relevant role played by context when\ndeciding whether a message is abusive or not. How-\never, additional work is needed to ﬁnd better ap-\nproaches for effectively including context in the\nclassiﬁcation. Previous analyses on Wikipedia\n(Karan and Šnajder, 2019; Pavlopoulos et al., 2020)\nhighlighted similar difﬁculties in modelling the tex-\ntual content of a thread for automated classiﬁcation.\nOur case is even more challenging because of a ma-\njor difference between Twitter and other platforms:\nwhile on other social networks, whose goal is to\nexplicitly discuss a topic, it is rather easy to extract\na conversation graph, identifying posts and related\nreplies (see e.g. the conversation trees from Reddit\ndiscussions in Hessel and Lee (2019), the structure\nof Twitter threads is less stable. Indeed, the list\nof tweets that we extract to build a context is not\nnecessarily a sequence of replies in a coherent con-\nversation, but could include gaps created by deleted\nmessages. This could make the relation between\nan abusive message and its context not clear, since\nthe next messages are not necessarily a reaction to\nwhat was said before.\nReshaping abusive language annotation and de-\ntection as a task that should take the context into ac-\ncount is in our view relevant also because it would\ncontribute to mitigating the problem of disembodi-\nment in NLP (Waseem et al., 2020), i.e. the fact that\nboth data and machine learning encode subjective\ncontent that is however presented as universalised\nand objective, with the potential to create social\nmarginalisation. For the abusive language case,\nconsidering tweets in isolation would oversimplify\nthe way in which online abuses happen in reality,\nignoring the fact that context gives a more informed\nperspective on the circumstances that led to a sup-posed abuse. Although we are aware that abusive\nlanguage annotation is affected by different types\nof biases, ranging from data sampling (Wiegand\net al., 2019; Ousidhoum et al., 2020) to annota-\ntors’ preferences (Waseem, 2016), we believe that\nincluding the local context in the task deﬁnition\ncould be a ﬁrst step towards a fairer approach to\ndata annotation and classiﬁcation.\n9 Conclusions\nIn this work we investigate the role of textual con-\ntext in abusive language detection on Twitter. We\nﬁrst manually re-annotate the tweets in the dataset\nfrom (Founta et al., 2018) for which the preced-\ning tweets could be retrieved online. Annotation\nwas performed by the same crowd-workers in two\ndifferent time periods, asking them to take into ac-\ncount the context and then to annotate the tweets in\nisolation. A comparison between the two datasets\nshows that the context is sometimes necessary to\nunderstand the real intent of the user, and that it is\nmore likely to make a tweet non abusive, even if\nit contains profanities. We therefore recommend\nthat, in future annotation efforts for abusive lan-\nguage detection, the textual context of messages\nis also provided to annotators. This would have\nan impact also on the implementation of classiﬁ-\ncation systems, which should foresee strategies to\nembed contextual information: the task would be\nmore challenging, but also more similar to a real ap-\nplication scenario. Our classiﬁcation experiments\nsuggest also that the high performance achieved\nwith BERT-based systems in ‘standard’ abusive\nlanguage detection may be overly optimistic, be-\ncause when context is given in input to the same\nclassiﬁers and they are evaluated on context-aware\ndatasets, their performance drops dramatically.\nIn the future, we hope that the release of the\ndatasets presented in this paper and our initial ex-', 'periments will foster research in the direction of\ncontext-aware abusive language detection, includ-\ning both the creation of guidelines and annotated\ndata, as well as novel classiﬁcation approaches.\nAs a next step, we plan to investigate novel ways\nto model context, for example by analysing the\nrole of direct responses containing an explicit men-\ntion of the user. We also plan to further extend\nthis approach to other platforms, to assess whether\nplatform-speciﬁc differences can be observed re-\ngarding the role of context, along the line of what\nhas already been observed for single messages\n(Corazza et al., 2019).\nReferences\nHind Almerekhi, Haewoon Kwak, Bernard J. Jansen,\nand Joni Salminen. 2019. Detecting toxicity trig-\ngers in online discussions. In Proceedings of the\n30th ACM Conference on Hypertext and Social Me-\ndia, HT ’19, pages 291–292.\nJinYeong Bak, Suin Kim, and Alice Oh. 2012. Self-\ndisclosure and relationship strength in twitter con-\nversations. SemEval-2019 task 5: Multilin-\ngual detection of hate speech against immigrants\nand women in twitter. In Pro-\nceedings of the Sixth Italian Conference on Com-\nputational Linguistics, Bari, Italy, November 13-15,\n2019 , volume 2481 of CEUR Workshop Proceedings .\nCEUR-WS.org.\nCorinna Cortes and Vladimir Vapnik. 1995. Support-\nvector networks. Mach.
