In ESWC 2018: The\nsemantic web Conference Proceedings , pages 745–\n760. Springer Verlag.'], ["Toward Bias Analysis Using Tweets and Natural \nLanguage Processing \nEarl Tankard Jr., Christopher Flowers, Jiang Li and Danda B. Rawat \nDepartment of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science \nHoward University, Washington DC, 20059, USA \n{earl.tankard@bison., christopher.flower s1@bison., jli@, danda.rawat@}howard.edu \nAbstract — Whether intentionally or not, many individuals in \nsociety express some form of prejudice or bias in their thinking \nand communications. Prejudice can be expressed in a multitude of ways and may be directed towards anything in which people can \nhave an opinion. What makes prejudiced/biased thinking different \nand potentially more dangerous than having an opinion is that they are not always based on one’s personal experiences and therefore may be misinformed. With the rise of social media \nplatforms in the last 20 years or so, people have more ways than \never to express their opinions and share their voices. This paper defines an approach to using Twitter, one of the most popular modern-day social media platforms, to analyze an individual’s \ntweets for the purposes of identifying potential biases. Using \nsentiment analysis along with other natural language processing tools, a score of potential bias of an individual user is calculated. This score can provide insight to the degree and/or frequency at which a person can be expected to exhibit biased behavior or make \nbiased statements and is only meant to serve as a reference. \nKeywords- analysis, bias, social media, sentiment, tokenize, NLP \nI. INTRODUCTION \nSince its founding in 2006, Twitter has grown to become one \nof the largest and most frequently used social media platforms \nof the 21st century, amassing 330 million monthly active users. As a platform used to share news and other current events, music and entertainment, personal status updates, and other \nmedia, Twitter is rich with data to be harvested and analyzed. \nThe data that Twitter users create through their own profiles is \nencapsulated in short microblog posts called “tweets” which can be anywhere from one to two-hundred-and-eighty characters and contain a variety of elements. Through collecting tweets and dissecting these characters and elements, \ndifferent types of analysis can be performed. \n \nPrior research has been done to conduct sentiment analysis \non tweets, which looks at temporary feelings held in regard to \na subject. In addition to analyzin g tweets, interesting analysis \ncan be conducted by viewing the frequency of tweets pertaining to different subject areas. Using sentiment analysis, various \nnatural language processing tools, and measuring the number \nof times bad words appear in a specific user's recent tweet history, we attempt to understand the bias presented by a particular user. \n \nThrough the use of the bias calculator, we were able to \ngenerate scores for politicians, en tertainers, athletes and more. \nIn section two, we define key terms and the algorithm used to generate the bias score. In section three, we provide examples of results received from the bias calculator. Section four presents a brief analysis of the results in section three as well as \nplans for the future. In section five and six we discuss previous \nresearch conducted in the social media sentiment analysis space and the conclusion.\n \nII. METHODOLOGY \nThe biased score calculator that we designed utilizes a series \nof GET requests in order to acquire the data the user desires. \nWe made use of the Twitter API [1] in order to fetch the tweets \nin an organized manner. \nTo facilitate the following discussion, a few key terms are \ndefined below. \nBias is a binary thought or opinion, which is usually regarded \nas unfair, towards an object, person or idea commonly resulting from subconscious beliefs. We consider that bias is persistent formed over one’s long-time past experience. \n \nSentiment is an emotion held in regard towards an object, \nperson, or idea that can be positive, negative, or neutral. We consider that sentiment is temporary and triggered by certain \nevents. We further assume that the sentiment expressed towards \nan event has strong correlation with one’s bias and therefore use sentiment in the calculation of the bias score (to be explained below). \n \nBad words (BWs) are words that frequently have a negative \nconnotation in context. The reason we chose these words is so \nwe can establish a baseline for our scoring mechanism. BWs \nmake it easier to filter “bad” tweets, or tweets that we want to analyze. For instance, say a tweet is “I am not a happy person”. The sentiment of the sentence is negative; however, since there are no words present from our list of BWs, we ignore the tweet and move on to the next.\n \nIn order to construct our list of BWs, we pulled tweets from \nmultiple twitter accounts ranging from politicians to gamers to actors. Within those tweets, we searched for recurring words with a negative connotation. We selected our negative words through subjective judgement and target words that appeared \nover one-hundred times in thousands of tweets. Our Bad Words \nconsist of multiple categories of words, including verbs, \nadjectives, and nouns. Some of the verbs are abort, dismantle, \nand jeopardize . Some of the adjectives are corrupt, restrictive, \nand the f-word+ ing. Some of the nouns include racially charged \nwords, such as the n-word . \n \nIn the pilot work, we chose to focus only on the negative \ntweets (tweets that are disrespectful or are against people, places, organizations, etc.) in order to simplify the score 2021 IEEE 18th Annual Consumer Communications & Networking Conference (CCNC)\n978-1-7281-9794-4/21/$31.00 ©2021 IEEE2021 IEEE 18th Annual Consumer Communications &amp; Networking Conference (CCNC) | 978-1-7281-9794-4/21/$31.00 ©2021 IEEE | DOI: 10.1109/CCNC49032.2021.9369461\nAuthorized licensed use limited to: University of Texas at Austin. Downloaded on October 24,2022 at 19:38:25 UTC from IEEE Xplore. Restrictions apply. ", 'calculation process. Positive tw eets will be included in the \nstudy in the future. \nThe algorithm to calculate the bias score of a Twitter user is \npresented below as Algorithm 1. \n \nAlgorithm 1 : Estimate Bias Score of a Twitter User Account \n \nBiasScoreGenerator : Compute biasScore \nInput : \n tweets : array of tweet strings from Twitter API \n badWords : array of predefined bad words \nOutput: \n biasScore : negatively biased score of a Twitter account \n \nInitialize the set of flaggedTweets \nfor each tweet in tweets do \nRemove URLs from the tweet \nRetrieve the word tokens from the tweet \nif the tweet has no token then \n Skip this token and process next one \nend if \n Calculate sentimentScore of the tweet [2] \nif the tweet has negative sentiment (sentimentScore < 0) and contains a \nBW then \nAdd tweet to flaggedTweets \nend if \nend for \nif there are no tweets in flaggedTweets then \nreturn biasScore as 0 \nend if \nInitialize the set of biasedTweets \nfor each tweet in flaggedTweets do \n for each non-empty sentence in the tweet do \n Get proper nouns [3] and pronouns from the sentence \n if the sentence has either type of noun and has a BW then \n Add the tweet to biasedTweets \n end if \n end for \nend for \nif biasedTweets is empty then \nreturn biasScore as 0 \nend if \nbiasScore ← 0 \nflScore ← 0 \nbiScore ← 0 \nfor each tweet in flaggedTweets do \n flScore ← flScore + sentimentScore of the tweet \nend for \nflScore ← flScore / (5 * number of tweets in flaggedTweets) \nfor each tweet in biasedTweets do \n biScore ← biScore + sentimentScore of the tweet) \nend for \nbiScore ← (biScore / (5 * number of tweets in biasedTweets)) * weight \nbiasScore ← sqrt(flScore * biScore*100) \nreturn biasScore \n \nThe weight in the calculation of biScore in the algorithm was \nintroduced to balance between biScore and flScore . The value \nof 25 was used in our experiments. The exact impacts of this \nparameter will be explored in the future. \nIII. RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS \nWe tested our algorithm on multiple Twitter accounts of \nwhich the public has clear perceptions. We chose accounts of people that, in the public eye, are generally known to have bias. This bias could be a political party, a belief, or something else.\n As of 28 August 2020, the scores of the following \npeople/organizations using our demo site [4] are as shown in Table I. \nTable I. Score for Given Twitter Account Name \nName screen_name Score (%)\nAzealia Banks @CHPYXO 68.21 \nBarack Obama @BarackObama 18.83 \nBernie Sanders @BernieSanders 44.23 \nChelsea Handler @chelseahandler 56.08 \nCNN Breaking \nNews@cnnbrk 47.24 \nDonald Trump @realDonaldTrump \n@POTUS 34.89 \n52.10 \nHulk Hogan @HulkHogan 15.52 \nRobert Beckel @RobertGBeckel 48.43 \nTerry Crews @terrycrews 42.61 \nThe New York \nTimes@nytimes 53.22 \n \nThe scores basically agree with what the public sees these \nentities to be. We chose to analyze political figures and \norganizations because they tend to have the most obvious bias. \nWe have noticed that the scores could change. Since the most \nrecent 3200 tweets are retrieved for analysis, whenever a user \nadds a new tweet or retweets something, their score may change. For users that do not post that often, their score does not change much. The opposite can be said for users that frequently post to the Twitter platform. In the six months (January 2020 - August 2020) that we have analyzed tweets, the \nscores for some individuals have fluctuated dramatically. This \nmakes the study of how the score changes over time another topic of interest as a future work.\n \nIV. RELATED WORKS \nThere has been a wide array of research projects focused on \nconducting sentiment analysis on data accessible via social media applications. A literature review by Drus and Khalid [5] lists off many of these projects and typical sentiment analysis has been done in [8]. All of the conducted research projects use lexicon-based analytical tools or machine learning tools to \nconduct sentiment analysis for a variety of applications \nincluding evaluating business performance, determining trends \nand characteristics of people, and understanding how people feel towards a specific topic. The compiled research projects show just how many opportunities exist in the space of sentiment analysis, specifically as it pertains to social media. Such research projects bear similarity to the project described \nin this paper and yet have some delicate difference. \n 2021 IEEE 18th Annual Consumer Communications & Networking Conference (CCNC)\nAuthorized licensed use limited to: University of Texas at Austin. Downloaded on October 24,2022 at 19:38:25 UTC from IEEE Xplore. Restrictions apply. ', 'Kharde and Sonawane [6] use multiple sentiment analysis \nmethods (machine learning, lexicon-based, cross-lingual, and \ncross-domain approaches) and provide a comparative study of \nthe techniques. Multiple data sets are used to test the methods, \nwhich are then compared in terms of percent accuracy. The data \nused includes positively and negatively categorized tweets, movie reviews,opinions, and more. Before using the different methods, tweets go through preprocessing to remove important symbols and text (emoticons & URLS). In addition to looking \nat sentiment analysis, the aforementioned research also \nanalyzes subjectivity and opinions held by conducting analysis at the word, sentence and document level. \n \nThe proposed research can be likened to that of Kharde and \nSonawane’s [6] because both projects require some degree of sentiment analysis. Sentiment analysis is an important aspect of \nboth projects, but the research described in this paper is focused \non conducting a bias analysis. The key difference between these types of analyses is that sentiment analysis looks at one-time \nemotions conveyed in text while bias analysis looks at \npersistent opinions expressed in text. One of the goals of the research discussed in this paper is to detect the presence of bias.\n \nWakade, Shekar, Liszka, and Chan [7] use decision trees to \nrepresent their results for purposes of judging the sentiment of new tweets. One aspect of this research to take note of is the size of the data set used. A set of 10.5 million tweets compiled from over 200,000 users was used, enabling extensive training \nof a machine learning algorithm. To begin the training, a set of \ntweets related to the same subject were collected. The words in those tweets were then compared to a list of 931 positive words downloaded from Winspiration and a list of 1838 negative words downloaded from EQI. Overall sentiment of each tweet is determined by adding the frequency of positive and negative \nwords that are present.\n \nThe work of Wakade, Shekar, Liszka, and Chan [7] is also \nfocused on conducting sentiment analysis on twitter data. Their \nresearch uses a decision tree method to classify tweet sentiment as opposed to multiple methods for a comparative study or conducting a bias analysis. Through conducting their research, \nthe authors were able to show that decision tree classifiers \nperform better than Bayes classifiers. The differentiation between sentiment and bias analysis serves as a distinguishing factor between the two research projects.\n \nAs previously mentioned, the pr oposed research attempts to \nconduct a bias analysis, which builds on top of sentiment analysis. Based on the assumption that sentiment analysis is to \nunderstand the short-term emotions held in regard to an object, \nperson, or idea, we use this information to build on top of and conduct a bias analysis. By identifying repeated sentiments directed towards specific subjects over an extended period of \ntime, we are able to conduct a bias analysis on a specific user. Leveraging the methodologies and understanding the results of previously conducted research on sentiment analysis may accelerate the development of a twitter based bias analysis tool.\n \nV. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK \nIn this paper, we discuss the methodology used and results \nreceived when attempting to calculate a bias score for a user on Twitter. The main factors co nsidered when identifying \npotential bias are sentiment and recurrence. The current implementation only focuses on negative sentiment. \n \nIn future work, analysis of positive sentiment will be \nconducted while also working to understand sentiment as it relates to a specific subject. We will also consider leveraging the work on sentiment analysis aforementioned. With sentiment \nanalysis as the basis of bias analysis, that could lead to more accurate detection of bias. We have also considered calculating \nand checking the difference between the bias of an account over \ntime. This could yield interesting results, especially since many users that we have analyzed tweet quite frequently \nA\nCKNOWLEDGEMENTS \nThis work was supported by the U.S. NSF under grant IIS \n#1924092 and by the DoD Center of Excellence in AI and \nMachine Learning (CoE-AIML) at Howard University under \nContract Number W911NF-20-2-0277 with the U.S. Army Research Laboratory. However, any opinion, finding, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author and do not necessarily reflect the views of \nthese funding agencies. \nR\nEFERENCES \n[1] "Documentation Home", Developer.twitter.com , 2020. [Online]. \nAvailable: https://developer.twitter.com/en/docs. [Accessed: 28- Aug- \n2020]. \n[2] "@happyaccident/wink-sentiment", npm, 2020. [Online]. Available: \nhttps://www.npmjs.com/package/@happyaccident/wink-sentiment. \n[Accessed: 28- Aug- 2020]. \n[3] "compromise", npm, 2020. [Online]. Available: \nhttps://www.npmjs.com/package/compromise. Khalid, "Sentiment Analysis in Social Media and Its \nApplication: Systematic Literature Review", Procedia Computer Science , \nvol. 161, pp. 707-714, 2019. Sonawane, "Sentiment Analysis of Twitter Data: A Survey \nof Techniques", International Journal of Computer Applications , vol. \n139, no. 11, pp. 5-15, 2016. Available: 10.5120/ijca2016908625. \n[7] S. Wakade, C. Shekar, K. Liszka and C. Chan, "Text Mining for \nSentiment Analysis of Twitter Data", University of Akron, 2012. \n[8] Ghaida Alorini, Danda B. Step 2: Fix Errors

  • Examine the text for errors or problems by looking at the text (done above).
  • Deal with the issues involved in HTML.

# x = re.search("The scientific method is an empirical method for acquiring", texts[0]).span(0)[0] #Find the index for the start of this string
# texts[0] = (texts[0])[x:] #Extracts the string from the sentence above to the end of the text
