Springer Verlag.']
— Whether intentionally or not, many individuals in society express some form of prejudice or bias in their thinking and communications. Prejudice can be expressed in a multitude of ways and may be directed towards anything in which people can have an opinion. What makes prejudiced/biased thinking different and potentially more dangerous than having an opinion is that they are not always based on one’s personal experiences and therefore may be misinformed. With the rise of social media platforms in the last 20 years or so, people have more ways than ever to express their opinions and share their voices. This paper defines an approach to using Twitter, one of the most popular modern-day social media platforms, to analyze an individual’s tweets for the purposes of identifying potential biases. Using sentiment analysis along with other natural language processing tools, a score of potential bias of an individual user is calculated. This score can provide insight to the degree and/or frequency at which a person can be expected to exhibit biased behavior or make biased statements and is only meant to serve as a reference. Keywordsanalysis, bias, social media, sentiment, tokenize, NLP I. INTRODUCTION Since its founding in 2006, Twitter has grown to become one of the largest and most frequently used social media platforms of the 21st century, amassing 330 million monthly active users. As a platform used to share news and other current events, music and entertainment, personal status updates, and other media, Twitter is rich with data to be harvested and analyzed. The data that Twitter users create through their own profiles is encapsulated in short microblog posts called “tweets” which can be anywhere from one to two-hundred-and-eighty characters and contain a variety of elements. Through collecting tweets and dissecting these characters and elements, different types of analysis can be performed. Prior research has been done to conduct sentiment analysis on tweets, which looks at temporary feelings held in regard to a subject. In addition to analyzin g tweets, interesting analysis can be conducted by viewing the frequency of tweets pertaining to different subject areas. Using sentiment analysis, various natural language processing tools, and measuring the number of times bad words appear in a specific user's recent tweet history, we attempt to understand the bias presented by a particular user. Through the use of the bias calculator, we were able to generate scores for politicians, en tertainers, athletes and more. In section two, we define key terms and the algorithm used to generate the bias score. In section three, we provide examples of results received from the bias calculator. Section four presents a brief analysis of the results in section three as well as plans for the future. In section five and six we discuss previous research conducted in the social media sentiment analysis space and the conclusion. II. METHODOLOGY The biased score calculator that we designed utilizes a series of GET requests in order to acquire the data the user desires. We made use of the Twitter API [1] in order to fetch the tweets in an organized manner. To facilitate the following discussion, a few key terms are defined below. Bias is a binary thought or opinion, which is usually regarded as unfair, towards an object, person or idea commonly resulting from subconscious beliefs. We consider that bias is persistent formed over one’s long-time past experience. Sentiment is an emotion held in regard towards an object, person, or idea that can be positive, negative, or neutral. We consider that sentiment is temporary and triggered by certain events. We further assume that the sentiment expressed towards an event has strong correlation with one’s bias and therefore use sentiment in the calculation of the bias score (to be explained below). Bad words (BWs) are words that frequently have a negative connotation in context. The reason we chose these words is so we can establish a baseline for our scoring mechanism. BWs make it easier to filter “bad” tweets, or tweets that we want to analyze. For instance, say a tweet is “I am not a happy person”. The sentiment of the sentence is negative; however, since there are no words present from our list of BWs, we ignore the tweet and move on to the next. In order to construct our list of BWs, we pulled tweets from multiple twitter accounts ranging from politicians to gamers to actors. Within those tweets, we searched for recurring words with a negative connotation. We selected our negative words through subjective judgement and target words that appeared over one-hundred times in thousands of tweets. Our Bad Words consist of multiple categories of words, including verbs, adjectives, and nouns. Some of the verbs are abort, dismantle, and jeopardize . Some of the adjectives are corrupt, restrictive, and the f-word+ ing. Some of the nouns include racially charged words, such as the n-word . In the pilot work, we chose to focus only on the negative tweets (tweets that are disrespectful or are against people, places, organizations, etc.) in order to simplify the score 2021 IEEE 18th Annual Consumer Communications & Networking Conference (CCNC) 978-1-7281-9794-4/21/$31.00 ©2021 IEEE2021 IEEE 18th Annual Consumer Communications &amp; Networking Conference (CCNC) | 978-1-7281-9794-4/21/$31.00 ©2021 IEEE | DOI: 10.1109/CCNC49032.2021.9369461 Authorized licensed use limited to: University of Texas at Austin. Downloaded on October 24,2022 at 19:38:25 UTC from IEEE Xplore. Restrictions apply. ", 'calculation process. Positive tw eets will be included in the study in the future. The algorithm to calculate the bias score of a Twitter user is presented below as Algorithm 1. Algorithm 1 : Estimate Bias Score of a Twitter User Account BiasScoreGenerator : Compute biasScore Input : tweets : array of tweet strings from Twitter API badWords : array of predefined bad words Output: biasScore : negatively biased score of a Twitter account Initialize the set of flaggedTweets for each tweet in tweets do Remove URLs from the tweet Retrieve the word tokens from the tweet if the tweet has no token then Skip this token and process next one end if Calculate sentimentScore of the tweet [2] if the tweet has negative sentiment (sentimentScore < 0) and contains a BW then Add tweet to flaggedTweets end if end for if there are no tweets in flaggedTweets then return biasScore as 0 end if Initialize the set of biasedTweets for each tweet in flaggedTweets do for each non-empty sentence in the tweet do Get proper nouns [3] and pronouns from the sentence if the sentence has either type of noun and has a BW then Add the tweet to biasedTweets end if end for end for if biasedTweets is empty then return biasScore as 0 end if biasScore ← 0 flScore ← 0 biScore ← 0 for each tweet in flaggedTweets do flScore ← flScore + sentimentScore of the tweet end for flScore ← flScore / (5 * number of tweets in flaggedTweets) for each tweet in biasedTweets do biScore ← biScore + sentimentScore of the tweet) end for biScore ← (biScore / (5 * number of tweets in biasedTweets)) * weight biasScore ← sqrt(flScore * biScore*100) return biasScore The weight in the calculation of biScore in the algorithm was introduced to balance between biScore and flScore . The value of 25 was used in our experiments. The exact impacts of this parameter will be explored in the future. III. RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS We tested our algorithm on multiple Twitter accounts of which the public has clear perceptions. We chose accounts of people that, in the public eye, are generally known to have bias. This bias could be a political party, a belief, or something else. As of 28 August 2020, the scores of the following people/organizations using our demo site [4] are as shown in Table I. Table I. Score for Given Twitter Account Name Name screen_name Score (%) Azealia Banks @CHPYXO 68.21 Barack Obama @BarackObama 18.83 Bernie Sanders @BernieSanders 44.23 Chelsea Handler @chelseahandler 56.08 CNN Breaking News@cnnbrk 47.24 Donald Trump @realDonaldTrump @POTUS 34.89 52.10 Hulk Hogan @HulkHogan 15.52 Robert Beckel @RobertGBeckel 48.43 Terry Crews @terrycrews 42.61 The New York Times@nytimes 53.22 The scores basically agree with what the public sees these entities to be. We chose to analyze political figures and organizations because they tend to have the most obvious bias. We have noticed that the scores could change. Since the most recent 3200 tweets are retrieved for analysis, whenever a user adds a new tweet or retweets something, their score may change. For users that do not post that often, their score does not change much. The opposite can be said for users that frequently post to the Twitter platform. In the six months (January 2020 August 2020) that we have analyzed tweets, the scores for some individuals have fluctuated dramatically. This makes the study of how the score changes over time another topic of interest as a future work. IV. RELATED WORKS There has been a wide array of research projects focused on conducting sentiment analysis on data accessible via social media applications. A literature review by Drus and Khalid [5] lists off many of these projects and typical sentiment analysis has been done in [8]. All of the conducted research projects use lexicon-based analytical tools or machine learning tools to conduct sentiment analysis for a variety of applications including evaluating business performance, determining trends and characteristics of people, and understanding how people feel towards a specific topic. The compiled research projects show just how many opportunities exist in the space of sentiment analysis, specifically as it pertains to social media. Such research projects bear similarity to the project described in this paper and yet have some delicate difference. 2021 IEEE 18th Annual Consumer Communications & Networking Conference (CCNC) Authorized licensed use limited to: University of Texas at Austin. Downloaded on October 24,2022 at 19:38:25 UTC from IEEE Xplore. Restrictions apply. ', 'Kharde and Sonawane [6] use multiple sentiment analysis methods (machine learning, lexicon-based, cross-lingual, and cross-domain approaches) and provide a comparative study of the techniques. Multiple data sets are used to test the methods, which are then compared in terms of percent accuracy. The data used includes positively and negatively categorized tweets, movie reviews,opinions, and more. Before using the different methods, tweets go through preprocessing to remove important symbols and text (emoticons & URLS). In addition to looking at sentiment analysis, the aforementioned research also analyzes subjectivity and opinions held by conducting analysis at the word, sentence and document level. The proposed research can be likened to that of Kharde and Sonawane’s [6] because both projects require some degree of sentiment analysis. Sentiment analysis is an important aspect of both projects, but the research described in this paper is focused on conducting a bias analysis. The key difference between these types of analyses is that sentiment analysis looks at one-time emotions conveyed in text while bias analysis looks at persistent opinions expressed in text. One of the goals of the research discussed in this paper is to detect the presence of bias. Wakade, Shekar, Liszka, and Chan [7] use decision trees to represent their results for purposes of judging the sentiment of new tweets. One aspect of this research to take note of is the size of the data set used. A set of 10.5 million tweets compiled from over 200,000 users was used, enabling extensive training of a machine learning algorithm. To begin the training, a set of tweets related to the same subject were collected. The words in those tweets were then compared to a list of 931 positive words downloaded from Winspiration and a list of 1838 negative words downloaded from EQI. Overall sentiment of each tweet is determined by adding the frequency of positive and negative words that are present. The work of Wakade, Shekar, Liszka, and Chan [7] is also focused on conducting sentiment analysis on twitter data. Their research uses a decision tree method to classify tweet sentiment as opposed to multiple methods for a comparative study or conducting a bias analysis. Through conducting their research, the authors were able to show that decision tree classifiers perform better than Bayes classifiers. The differentiation between sentiment and bias analysis serves as a distinguishing factor between the two research projects. As previously mentioned, the pr oposed research attempts to conduct a bias analysis, which builds on top of sentiment analysis. Based on the assumption that sentiment analysis is to understand the short-term emotions held in regard to an object, person, or idea, we use this information to build on top of and conduct a bias analysis. By identifying repeated sentiments directed towards specific subjects over an extended period of time, we are able to conduct a bias analysis on a specific user. Leveraging the methodologies and understanding the results of previously conducted research on sentiment analysis may accelerate the development of a twitter based bias analysis tool. V. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK In this paper, we discuss the methodology used and results received when attempting to calculate a bias score for a user on Twitter. The main factors co nsidered when identifying potential bias are sentiment and recurrence. The current implementation only focuses on negative sentiment. In future work, analysis of positive sentiment will be conducted while also working to understand sentiment as it relates to a specific subject. We will also consider leveraging the work on sentiment analysis aforementioned. With sentiment analysis as the basis of bias analysis, that could lead to more accurate detection of bias. We have also considered calculating and checking the difference between the bias of an account over time. This could yield interesting results, especially since many users that we have analyzed tweet quite frequently A CKNOWLEDGEMENTS This work was supported by the U.S. NSF under grant IIS #1924092 and by the DoD Center of Excellence in AI and Machine Learning (CoE-AIML) at Howard University under Contract Number W911NF-20-2-0277 with the U.S. Army Research Laboratory. However, any opinion, finding, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author and do not necessarily reflect the views of these funding agencies. Step 3: Clean text with regex

  • Use the “impurity” function from class to examine the text for potential issues.
  • Remove the noise with the regex function.
  • Re-examine the impurity to determine if the data has been mostly cleaned.
#Step 3

import re

RE_SUSPICIOUS = re.compile(r'[&#<>{}\[\]\\]')

def impurity(text, min_len=10):
    """returns the share of suspicious characters in a text"""
    if text == None or len(text) < min_len:
        return 0
    else:
        return len(RE_SUSPICIOUS.findall(text))/len(text)
    
def clean_up(text):
    # tags like <tab>
    # find things that are < STUFF > that aren't <<>> because [^<>] means doesn't start with 
    text = re.sub(r'<[^<>]*>', ' ', text)
    # markdown URLs like [Some text](https://....)
    text = re.sub(r'\[([^\[\]]*)\]\([^\(\)]*\)', r'\1', text)
    # text or code in brackets like [0]
    text = re.sub(r'\[[^\[\]]*\]', ' ', text)
    # standalone sequences of specials, matches &# but not #cool
    text = re.sub(r'(?:^|\s)[&#<>{}\[\]+|\\:-]{1,}(?:\s|$)', ' ', text)
    # standalone sequences of hyphens like --- or ==
    text = re.sub(r'(?:^|\s)[\-=\+]{2,}(?:\s|$)', ' ', text)
    # get rid of bylines
    # starts with ( any number of characters in the middle and ends with )
    text = re.sub(r'^\(.*\)$', ' ', text)
    # sequences of white spaces
    text = re.sub(r'\s+', ' ', text)
    return text.strip()

#Applying to a list
for pdf in range(len(pdfs_list)):
    pdfs_list[pdf] = clean_up(str(pdfs_list[pdf]))
    print(impurity(str(pdf)))
    
0
0
0
#Applying to column in dataframe
df['impurity'] = df['Text'].apply(impurity)
df['impurity'].sort_values()

Step 4: Print output

  • Print out the first 1000 characters and the number of tokens in the text.
import nltk
nltk.download('punkt')

#Applying to list
for text in texts:
    print(str(text[0:1000]))
    print(len(word_tokenize(str(text))))

#Applying to dataframe
df['tokens'] = df['Text'].apply(word_tokenize)
df['tokens'].apply(len)

NEW YORK — Donald Trump became the first former president to be convicted of felony crimes Thursday as a New York jury found him guilty of falsifying business records in a scheme to illegally influence the 2016 election through hush money payments to a porn actor who said the two had sex.Jurors convicted Trump on all 34 counts after deliberating for 9.5 hours.The verdict is a stunning legal reckoning for Trump and exposes him to potential prison time in the city where his manipulations of the tabloid press helped catapult him from a real estate tycoon to reality television star and ultimately president. As he seeks a return to the White House in this year’s election, the judgment presents voters with another test of their willingness to accept Trump’s boundary-breaking behavior.Trump is expected to quickly appeal the verdict and will face an awkward dynamic as he seeks to return to the campaign trail as a convicted felon. Interpretation

  • Write a paragraph explaining the process of cleaning data for an NLP pipeline. You should explain the errors you found in the dataset and how you fixed them. Discuss the importance of text preprocessing to the NLP pipeline.

Answer

  • [Expectings 4-6 sentences describing how you had to process this specific set of texts not just the generic pipeline from the slides.]
